facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 66 and 67 of 1964 are before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDIVTION Civil Appeals Nos. 66 and 67 of 1964. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and decree of Allahabad High Court dated March 28, 1961 in Income-tax Reference No. 165 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree March 28, 1961 of the Allahabad High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 165 of 1954.

facts.text: Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills Ltd. carries on business of manufacturing jute goods.

anchor.surface_text: The Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills Ltd. carries on the business of manufacturing jute goods and is a member

facts.text: Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills Ltd. is a member of the Jute Mills Association.

anchor.surface_text: goods and is a member of the Jute Mills Association. To protect the members against loss resulting from

facts.text: Members of Jute Mills Association entered into agreement dated January 9, 1932 called First Working Time Agreement restricting hours of work, expiring December 11, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: To protect the members against loss resulting from overproduction, members of the Association entered into an agreement dated January 9, 1932 called the First Working Time Agreement restricting hours of work. That agreement was to expire on December 11, 1944.

facts.text: Fresh agreement executed on June 12, 1944 to continue the arrangement.

anchor.surface_text: With a view to companytinue the arrangement, a fresh agreement was executed on June 12, 1944.

facts.text: Agreement imposed restrictions on hours of work via loom-hours based on number of looms installed.

anchor.surface_text: By cl. 4 of the agreement, the association imposed restrictions upon the hours of work of its members. The number of hours for which the members were entitled to work their factories were called loom-hours. Allotment of loom-hours depended upon the number of looms installed in the factory of each member.

facts.text: Respondent allotted 220 x 72 loom-hours per week under the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was under the agreement allotted 220 x 72 hours per week.

facts.text: In account year corresponding to assessment year 1949-50, respondent's preparatory section unable to work looms more than 48 hours/week.

anchor.surface_text: In the account year companyresponding to the assessment year 1949-50, the preparatory section of the factory of the respondent was unable to work the looms for more than 48 hours a week,

facts.text: With sanction of Association, respondent sold 220 x 24 loom-hours to Naskarpara Jute Mills and received Rs. 53,460/- in account year for 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: and with the sanction of the Association the respondent sold 220 x 24 loom-hours to the Naskarpara Jute Mills and as companysideration of. the sale received Rs. 53,460/-.

facts.text: In account year corresponding to assessment year 1950-51, respondent received Rs. 1,85,230/- from Birla Jute Mills and Hanuman Jute Mills for sale of surplus loom-hours.

anchor.surface_text: In the account year companyresponding to the assessment year 1950-51 the respontdent received from the Birla Jute Mills and Hanuman Jute Mills a total amount of Rs. 1,85,230/- for sale of surplus loom-hours.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer included amounts received by sale of loom-hours in total income as revenue receipts for AY 1949-50 and 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment for the assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51 the Income-tax Officer included in the total income of the respondent the amounts received by sale of loom-hours as revenue receipts liable to tax.

facts.text: Order of Income-tax Officer confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income-tax Officer was companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: At instance of respondent, Tribunal referred question to Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the respondent, the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad

facts.text: Question referred: Whether receipts of Rs. 53,460/- and Rs. 1,85,230/- by sale of loom-hours in AY 1949-50 and 1950-51 were revenue receipts liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the receipts of the assessee by the sale of loom-hours amounting to Rs. 53,460/- and Rs. 1,85,230/- in the assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51 respectively were revenue receipts liable to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act?

facts.text: Allahabad High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the negative.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax preferred appeals with certificate under s.66A(2) of Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax has preferred these appeals with certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66-A  2  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Tribunal held receipts were not capital receipts, not casual or non-recurring.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the receipts in question were number capital receipts, number were they of a casual or number- recurring nature.

facts.text: Respondent pleaded receipts are casual and non-recurring exempt under s.4(3)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the respondent that the receipts for sale of loom-hours are number chargeable to tax because they are, within the meaning of s. 4 3   vii , casual and number-recurring, has numbersubstance.

facts.text: Supreme Court held receipts from sale of loom-hours are capital receipts not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: Receipt by sale of loom-hours must therefore be regarded in this case as a capital receipt and number income. In our judgment the High Court was right in holding that the receipts from sale of loom-hours were in the nature of capital receipts and were number taxable.

facts.text: Loom-hours regarded as asset capable of transfer subject to Association sanction.

anchor.surface_text: In the proceedings before the Income-tax auhorities the Tribunal and the High Court, these loom- hours have been regarded as an asset belong to each member

facts.text: Respondent unable to use full 72 hours/week due to inefficiency of preparatory section.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was unable, on account of inefficiency of its preparatory section, to supply the requisite material for running the factory for 72 hours per week which it was entitled to do.

holdings.text: The receipts from sale of loom-hours were in the nature of capital receipts and were not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: Receipt by sale of loom-hours must therefore be regarded in this case as a capital receipt and number income. In our judgment the High Court was right in holding that the receipts from sale of loom-hours were in the nature of capital receipts and were number taxable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Surplus loom-hours disposed of completely with no interest remaining; no exploitation by permitting user while retaining ownership; sale of fixed capital yields capital receipt.

holdings.text: The plea that the receipts for sale of loom-hours are not chargeable to tax because they are casual and non-recurring within s. 4(3)(vii) has no substance.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the respondent that the receipts for sale of loom-hours are number chargeable to tax because they are, within the meaning of s. 4 3   vii , casual and number-recurring, has numbersubstance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exemption under s.4(3)(vii) does not apply to receipts in ordinary course of business even if casual or non-recurring; not a business in loom-hours.

holdings.text: Loom-hours have been regarded as an asset belonging to each member capable of being transferred subject to sanction of the Association.

anchor.surface_text: In the proceedings before the Income-tax auhorities the Tribunal and the High Court, these loom- hours have been regarded as an asset belong to each member and in companysidering these appeals we do number think we would be justified allowing companynsel to raise a companytention  as was sought to be-done  that loom-hours were in the nature of a privilege and were number an asset at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Case considered throughout on footing that right to allotted loom-hours is transferable asset; no justification to raise contrary contention now.

holdings.text: Sale of assets used as fixed capital to carry on business results in capital receipt; sale of stock-in-trade or circulating capital results in trading receipt.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settLed that sale of stock-in-trade or circulating capital or rendering service in the companyrse of trading results in a trading receipt sale of assets which the assessee uses as fixed capital to enable him to carry on his business results in capital receipt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fundamental distinction in income-tax law; loom-hours part of fixed profit-making structure.

holdings.text: Loom-hours cannot be let out while retaining property; transaction is outright sale, not temporary user or exploitation while retaining ownership.

anchor.surface_text: Loom-hours cannot from their very nature be let out while retaining property in them, for there can be numbergrant of a temporary right to use loom-hours. Loom-hours are the asset of the respondent, but temporary user of the loom-hours cannot be granted. The transaction in this case is of sale of loom-hours.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished from cases like Lakshmi Silk Mills where asset let out temporarily retaining property; here complete disposal.

holdings.text: If compensation paid for agreeing to restraint on trade, such compensation would be capital.

anchor.surface_text: It is also companymon ground that for imposing restrictions upon the number of working hours, numbercompensation was paid to the members by the association or by any other body if it were, such companypensation being paid for agreeing to restraint on trade would be capital.

holdings.text: A receipt in the ordinary course of the assessee's business, even though casual or non-recurring, is taxable.

anchor.surface_text: But a receipt in the ordinary companyrse of the assessees business, even though it is casual or number-recurring, is by the express words used by the Legislature, taxable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express words of s.4(3)(vii) exclude business receipts from exemption.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Excess Profits, Bombay City v. Shri Lakshmi Silk Mills Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Excess Profits, Bombay City v. Shri Lakshmi Silk Mills Ltd. 1 . In Shri Lakshmi Silk Mills Ltd. case the assessee Company was a manufacturing concern and had for the purpose of its business installed a plant for dyeing silk yarn. For a part of the chargeable period the Company could not secure silk yarn and its plant remained idle.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Excess Profits, Bombay City v. Shri Lakshmi Silk Mills Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Receipt by the exploitation of a commercial asset is the profit of the business, irrespective of the manner in which the asset is exploited by the owner, whether by using it himself or letting it out to others
precedents.cited_holding: rent received by letting out an idle commercial asset temporarily is business income

precedents.citation: Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., Lucknow

anchor.surface_text: Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills v. precedents.cited_proposition: receipts from sale of surplus loom-hours are taxable as business profits from exploitation of commercial asset
precedents.cited_holding: loom-hours did not form the fixed profit-making structure of the business and sale thereof resulted in revenue receipt
